title: [Setup] Boto3 Installation
body:
## Description
During Tianjun's setup, when he installed Boto3 on his laptop, it installed every subversion of `boto3 1.20.{0…,40+}`.

## Fix

I tried replicating this bug on the Rise machines and my own personal laptop. It installed `boto3 1.21.26` and nothing else. Think this due to Tianjun's `pip` installer being too old. A fix could possibly be:

`pip install pip -U`

added to the documentation.

title: [Bug] Resource name conflict in shared Azure subscription
body:
@gmittal first ran
```
sky cpunode -c flax-test --cloud azure
```
After the VM is up, I ran the same command with the same cluster name again.
Then @gmittal can no longer log in to the CPU node he created.
I checked the web portal now there's only one `flax-test` VM launched by my Sky.
Looks like we need to modify the resource group name properly to avoid such conflicts.

title: Can sky down be parallelized?
body:
I created 20 clusters on Azure for testing purpose.
After testing, I'd like to `sky down -a` but terminating each Azure cluster is taking >5mins.
In total 100mins is needed to clean up all clusters.
Is it possible to send all the termination signals in parallel?

title: Back-compat: don't overwrite certain cluster configs in yaml if cluster exists
body:
Daniel has run into a back-compat issue, where
- he had a cluster launched before our AMI upgrade; it's in stopped state
- he upgraded Sky, which now includes the default AMI upgrade
- now, commands like `sky start/launch` would write out a new cluster yaml with the new AMI
- this causes the ray autoscaler to fail to reuse the previously launched cluster -- instead it launches new nodes

The solution is to not overwrite certain cluster configs in yaml if the cluster exists in our status table:
- Looking at `aws-ray.yml.j2`, it seems like everything below and including `file_mounts` can and should be overwritten (e.g., to get updated sky builds / runtime setup).  Everything above it is about the cluster config and should be kept static.

title: ILP-based DAG Optimizer
body:
Fixes #556.

The ILP formulation can be found [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1g0Vv_ZmgDd6OAnNJ0p4zQQ-iGjYlMn66/view?usp=sharing).

This PR also includes a random DAG generator and a brute-force solver.

Tested:
* `examples/example_app.py` (cost & time)
* `tests/test_optimizer_random_dag.py` (num_tasks=10).

**NOTE: This PR adds an ILP package `pulp` into `setup.py`. You should install this package to test the new optimizer on non-chain DAGs.**

## Discussion: Do we need the DP-based optimizer?

Since the new ILP-based optimizer can be used for any Sky DAGs, it is questionable that we should continue to use the DP algorithm for chain DAGs. Here are pros and cons:

* Pros:
  * The DP algorithm is probably easier to manipulate and debug.

* Cons:
  * Not good for maintenance.

I think we can have both algorithms for now, but we should slowly deprecate the DP algorithm to reduce redundancy. WDYT?

title: Roll back to debian-based image for GCP
body:
GCP's ubuntu image seems problematic and caused issues like https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/633, https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/618.
This PR rolls back to previous image based on debian and uses updated cuda library image for GPU VMs.

title: Added sky down --purge
body: Added `sky down --purge` which allows a user to remove a cluster from Sky ignoring any errors that the cloud provider throws (i.e ResourceNotFound). Useful for when the user manually plays around with resources or sky launch is called but terminated before any resources are created.

body:
Daniel reported:

I accidentally terminated an instance in the EC2 web console that corresponded to a STOPPED cluster (I thought it was one of the rogue instances). Now I can't remove the cluster from the sky interface:
```
$ sky down vasp
Terminating 1 cluster: vasp. Proceed? [Y/n]: y
```

title: UX: Hard to find logs (setup.log) corresponding to a cluster
body:
Daniel reported:
> I have a cluster that's up, and I want to view the provision log. There are plenty of provision.log files under ~/.sky_logs, but I don't know which one corresponds to this cluster. Is there any way to find out?
> oh, yeah I guess I'm probably more interested in setup.log than in provision.log

With the suggested workaround:
```
ray get-head-ip ~/.sky/generated/<name>.yml
grep -l 35.226.48.203 ~/sky_logs/**/provision.log
```
He said
> when I grep for the head node it returns a directory that only has provision.log (no other file). Probably because the most recent command was sky start  rather than sky launch ?

Finally his ultimate goal
>I just forgot what happened when I launched that cluster. I'd feel more comfortable down ing it if I e.g. check the setup log and see that it was one of the ones where setup failed

-----

Proposal: group logs under cluster name:

```
~/sky_logs/
  cluster0/
    sky-2022-03-22-18-18-40-093482/
    sky-2022-03-22-18-13-14-963869/
    ...
  my-other-cluster/
    ...
```
Alternatively, make the log dir contain the cluster name.

This should be doable here: https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/master/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L1148-L1149.

title: Refactor DAG optimizer
body:
Closes #545.

This PR refactors the Sky DAG optimizer. This PR includes:
* breaking up the `_optimize_cost` function, which was quite long (~170 lines) and a bit hard to follow. Now the optimization process is split into multiple smaller stages/functions.
* simplifying the DP algorithm by restricting the input graphs to chain DAGs. As reported in #556, the DP algorithm is not applicable to non-chain DAGs. So I pruned out the code for non-chain DAGs.
* more clearly printing the estimated run time and estimated cost. Now the optimizer prints both estimated run time and estimated total cost.
 
  * Before:
```bash
$ python examples/example_app.py
Optimizer - plan minimizing cost (~$57.1):
```
*
  * After: 
```bash
$ python examples/example_app.py
Optimizer - plan minimizing cost
Estimated Run time: ~21.7 hr, Cost: ~$57.1
```
* fixing a bug in printing the DAG optimization result.

NOTE: the problem in #556 is not fixed by this PR. The problem will fixed by #637, which should be merged after this PR.

Tested:
* `examples/example_app.py`
* smoke tests.

title: Potential bug: `sky start` should restrict zones to the exact zone used
body:
For example, a started AWS cluster could have 
```
availability_zone: us-east-1a,us-east-1b,...,us-east-1f
```
in its YAML while being really provisioned in `us-east-1a`.  Then it is stopped.  Now users `sky start` it, and let's say `1a` somehow ran out of capacity.  Then, it is **plausible (unconfirmed)** boto3 would automatically try `1b, 1c, ..., 1f` which is not what we want (the stopped instance may have data on it).  

Marking this as a potential bug to investigate whether the above could happen.  This affects both the AWS and GCP YAMLs.

This is related to the problem Daniel mentioned, though not exactly that bug.

title: [Feature request] Auto-capture bash history and allow user to instantiate Task.setup from it
Make `sky logs -s` support glob pattern on the job IDs
body:
Feature request from Daniel:

> I have 32 jobs and I want to search all of them for certain keywords (to match script outputs with wandb runs based on the wandb run name). Right now I'm running
for j in `seq 56 87`; do sky logs -s myclus $j; done
and then I'm planning to grep the logs locally, but **syncing each log takes a long time**. I tried sky logs -s myclus "*" but got an error. It's not a huge deal to wait, but is there any way to sync a bunch of logs all at once?

It'd be ideal to support globing job IDs, e.g., `sky logs -s myclus "*"`, when `-s` is specified.

(Also, the current `sky logs -s` code path does one roundtrip to get the log dir, then does another for the actual rsync.  We may want to optimize this a bit.)

title: OOM will cause the ray job fail
body:
When the system is about to run out of memory, `ray job submit` and `ray job stop` will fail (`submit` will say the task is successfully submitted, but `ray job status` will say it was failed; `stop` will keep waiting for the job to be killed forever), that the user cannot even kill a process. 

One way to fix this may be that we abort the whole usage of `ray job` and track the `pid` of tasks by ourselves.

title: Job status will remain in `INIT` if the generated ray program is killed by system
body: It is possible for the generated ray program to be killed by the system due to OOM. That may leave the job status in our `job_table` to be `INIT` or `RUNNING` state. We can have a service updating the job queue based on the `ray job status`. Mentioned in #616

title: Optimize the `sky job queue` when large amount of jobs running
body:
Closes #612. This PR optimizes the `sky job queue` time from 24 seconds to 1.4 seconds when there are 30 jobs running. (To have 30 jobs running together, we need to change the original placement_group setting of CPUs to smaller than 1 to allow more jobs than CPU cores.)

```
# With 30 jobs running
# Old sky queue
sky queue old-jq-test  0.95s user 0.27s system 5% cpu 23.932 total

# New sky queue
sky queue  0.98s user 0.25s system 86% cpu 1.422 total
```

The previous implementation will update the job status for each job when `sky queue` is called, using `ray job status`.  It will introduce significant overheads. Since our tasks will actively update their own status in the `job_table` and the job status update will only be used for dealing with the staled jobs caused by the cluster's stop and restart, it is OK to only update the status during the provision.

2. We can utilize some `python>= 3.7` subprocess feature, e.g. `capture_output`. (not very urgent)

title: [Docker] file_mounts are not available during setup in Docker
body:
`file_mounts` are not available in setup when running in docker. 

eg.
```
file_mounts:
    ~/.aws: ~/.aws

setup: |
    cat ~/.aws/credentials    # This would fail

run: |
    cat ~/.aws/credentials    # This is successful
```

This is a fundamental limitation - docker volume mounts are not mounted during image build stage. They are mounted only when the container run. 

A potential fix we could have is to run setup after the container is provisioned. In effect, this would not build an image with the setup run, but instead run the setup after the container is already running. This is probably not a good practice since we lose the packaging features of containers and provisioning time would increase significantly.

A workaround is to include files that are required during setup in your `workdir`.

title: [WIP] Enable multi-task on Sky
body:
Currently Sky only supports single task per DAG. This is an initial PR to run multiple independent tasks on Sky. One application enabled by this PR is racing benchmark where each task requires different accelerators. Potentially in the future we'll support general DAG on Sky.

@WoosukKwon and I are working together to finish this PR. Feel free to leave any comments or suggestions!

- [x] Support Python interface
```
with sky.Dag() as dag:
    task = []
    for acc in ['K80', 'V100']:
        task.append(sky.Task(run='nvidia-smi').set_resources(sky.Resources(accelerators={acc: 1})))
```
- [ ] Support YAML interface
- [ ] Cleanup output messages from different tasks
- [ ] Fix broken line breaks of messages
- [ ] Support terminating all tasks in DAG

title: Unique cluster name list for sky down
body: This is a small PR to make the `sky down` cluster name list unique before tearing down or stopping. Otherwise, `sky down env env jq` will fail due to the second `env` cluster will not have the ray yaml file.

title: [Docker] Install sudo in docker

title: [Docker] setup commands with sudo fail in --docker
body:
Sudo is not required (and not installed) in our base docker image, so any setup commands with sudo fail so:

`E 03-16 12:36:34 docker_utils.py:144] ./sky/sky_setup.sh: line 7: sudo: command not found`

This is problematic because the same commands require sudo to run on cloud providers (e.g., `sudo apt get install xyz` currently needs to be written as `apt get install xyz` for running on docker).

Potential fix is to alias sudo="$@" in docker so sudo commands act as pass through..

title: Fix order of setup

```yaml
  echo "start"

  echo "running setup"
```

title: `sky down` regex cluster name matching
body: It would be a good feature to have to support `sky down test-*`.

title: [Feature request] Can Sky support AWS regions outside US?
body:
Feedback from Daniel: "only three AWS regions are supported."
We may consider support more regions to increase Sky's availability. For example, [P3 instance](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/p3/) is available in 14 regions including some in Asia/Europe.

title: Add instructions in document for quota increase
body: To close https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/524, https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/513. We might also explore CLI interface to query quotas for convenience as mentioned in https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/447. Curious what people think.

title: Set $TPU_NAME during provisioning
body:
Closes #572. Still testing many things.

### Tests
- [x] `sky tpunode` works and echo $TPU_NAME is valid

```yaml
# min_tpu.yaml
resources:

num_nodes: 2
setup: |
  echo "setting up"

run: |

  echo $TPU_NAME
  echo "done"
```

title: Add --ignore-errors / -i flag to sky down/stop.
body:
During the testing of #584, I've encountered #570 where tearing down certain clusters failed due to missing yaml.  This prevented tearing down other, normal clusters, and I've found this flag to be useful.

Tested:
- `sky down -aiy` when the above happened, which tears down all normal clusters and leaves the abnormal ones in the table.

title: Parallel runner of smoke tests.
body:
The smoke tests can be run in ~30 minutes now.
- Example output: https://gist.github.com/concretevitamin/fb29a5a70691bed45a4f05d230b1d5c8
- It's bottlenecked by (approx) the slowest test, azure-start-stop, due to Azure's APIs being very slow

Also changed tpu delete script (cc @infwinston): 
 - discovered a race condition while testing this; it does make terminating tpu_app much longer.  But the slowest to teardown is probably still azure-start-stop.
 
-----

Tests:

  * Successful scenario
    - `time python -u examples/run_smoke.py 2>&1 | tee run.log`
      - 31:23.62 total
      - except tpu_app: (1) name bug #572; (2) we don't have a way to query a job's exit code (see below)

  * Tested multiple erroneous scenarios to ensure timeouts/error reporting/handling works as expected

-----

Future TODOs / known issues
 - [x] `sky logs --status cluster 1` or the like, to query a job's exit code
 - [ ] at the end of this script, concat all .log into one file so we can view it to ensure nothing is wrong (or auto grep for error/exception etc.)
  - [x] cannot ctrl-c the terminal that launches this script -- during or after the execution.
    - workaround: kill the window; if you want to ctrl-c in the middle to interrupt the tests: just run 'sky down -a -y' (assuming you have no other clusters) in another terminal, and the tests will error out
- [x] Our logging would mess up spacing for the terminal that runs this script (related to new line replacement?) after an error occurs / or just after a while
  - workaround: pipe to a file and view
  - cc @Michaelvll - this seems fairly easy to reproduce, e.g., just run the script for a while even with just `[minimal, multi_echo]`.
- [x] (cc @suquark) Starting all tests at the same time -- without staggering -- causes wheel builds to fail. See inlined TODOs. I added the workaround of staggering the starts + allowing each test to be retried once.

For the above reasons I tentatively didn't remove `run_smoke_tests.sh` - not feeling strongly about that, though.

title: Added timestamps to logging
body:
This does add a little bit of overhead so not entirely sure if it should be merged, but I found it helpful when I was exploring what happened in provisioning to have timestamps alongside the output & I think it would just make it a little easier to interpret the logs in general. Here's an example of what it looks like:

```
[2022-03-15 02:50:17] 2022-03-15 02:50:17,382   INFO util.py:282 -- setting max workers for head node type to 0
[2022-03-15 02:51:26] ** Message: 02:51:27.002: Remote error from secret service: org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.ServiceUnknown: The name org.freedesktop.secrets was not provided by any .service files
[2022-03-15 02:51:29] Cluster: sky-gpunode-mraheja
[2022-03-15 02:51:29] Traceback (most recent call last):
[2022-03-15 02:51:29]   File "/home/mraheja/.conda/envs/sky-full/bin/ray", line 8, in <module>
```

This could also be useful if we want to analyze the log files for profiling purposes in the future.

title: Allowed forced teardown when called within locked code
body:
Solves #576 by allowing forced teardown (which completes teardown without acquiring the cluster file lock) during already locked sections of the code--which right now is only provisioning.

Tested by manually setting `_force` to `True` and observing `sky down` proceed while provisioning still in progress.

title: Created and handled teardown success bool
body:
Added a success variable to teardown (`sky down`) which has the following benefits:

1. Makes it more clear when `sky down` has failed from a user perspective by surfacing it as a red result

```
(sky-full) mraheja@latte:~/Sky/sky$ sky down sky-cpunode-mraheja
Terminating 1 cluster: sky-cpunode-mraheja. Proceed? [Y/n]: y
E 03-15 02:11:49 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1743] Cluster sky-cpunode-mraheja is locked by /home/mraheja/.sky/.sky-cpunode-mraheja.lock. Check to see if it is still being launched.
Terminating cluster sky-cpunode-mraheja...failed.
```

2. Prevents deletion of YAML file if `sky down` fails by early termination of `_teardown()` #570 
3. Similarly, prevents deletion of lock file if `sky down` fails
4. Similarly, prevents removal of cluster from cluster table if `sky down` fails

title: Add worker nodes to local ssh config
body:
Currently, Sky only provides access to the head node of a cluster. This PR allows the users to easily connect to the worker nodes by adding them to the local ssh config.

Now the user can ssh into the 0-th worker node of a cluster `mycluster` by:
```bash
$ ssh mycluster-worker-0
```
Of course, I believe `scp/rsync mycluster-worker-0` should work as well.

title: Prune HTML files from git history
body:
`git filter-branch --force --index-filter 'git rm --cached --ignore-unmatch -r \*.html' --prune-empty -- --all`

Removes all the RTD auto-generated HTML files from a month back and makes our `.git` ~40MB smaller.

title: Add support for TPU VMs
body:
Currently Sky only supports TPU nodes, but an investigation by @infwinston and myself with our JAX experiments showed that Google is pushing all support to TPU VMs (see: https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/compute/introducing-cloud-tpu-vms) for JAX/newer frameworks (even Colab is backed by TPU VMs now). It is important that we support these types of machines as JAX is not compatible with the older TPU nodes.

iirc there was a discussion about a team at Berkeley needing TPU nodes, so we should find a way to support both.

title: Use `sky-{username}-{tpu_name}` naming scheme for TPU nodes since they are shared
body: It seems that TPUs are shared and it is not difficult for name conflicts to occur. We should do what we do for instances on shared accounts (like GCP, Azure) to prevent these name conflicts from occurring and use f`sky-{username}-{tpu_name}`.

title: Filelock disabled the teardown during `sky launch` for multiple nodes
body:
When we are trying to launch multiple nodes, it is possible to call teardown (during the launching) if the sky fails to launch enough nodes in that region. https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/c6955a4828987252052459726c06586f2d8ab15a/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L757 

@mraheja Can we try to add a _force option to that teardown function? When it is set, the teardown does not require the lock and does not delete the lock file.

title: Set $TPU_NAME during provisioning
body: Moved to #587 because of broken git history here.

body: Closes #573.

For example,

Though it print out the error messages, after I switched back to the correct environment and `sky down` again, it told me the ray yaml file does not exist. title: AWS G5 instance is not supported due to old driver version
body:
During the investigation of https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/pull/564 I found that the current AMI used by Sky can't support the G5 instance on AWS (which is the latest generation of G instance on AWS). The reason is the GPU driver version `450.142.00` is too old for A10 according to [here](https://docs.nvidia.com/datacenter/tesla/tesla-release-notes-450-142-00/index.html). We might need a better solution on choosing the right AMI for each instance.

```
ubuntu@ip-172-31-86-120:~$ nvidia-smi
NVIDIA-SMI has failed because it couldn't communicate with the NVIDIA driver. Make sure that the latest NVIDIA driver is installed and running.

ubuntu@ip-172-31-86-120:~$ modinfo nvidia | grep "version"
version:        450.142.00
```

title: Fix the lock logic for provision
body:
I separate this PR from #559, since this is a bit irrelevant with that PR.

L1128-L1148 should be locked to avoid race conditions with `teardown`. 
1. `teardown` can delete the row before L1143 adds an entry, causing the cluster has a `UP` status in the DB but actually killed.
2. `teardown` can delete the cluster_yaml before the read of L1146, causing the file loading failure.
3. `teardown` can remove the ssh entry before L1147, causing an entry in ssh config but actually killed.

@mraheja Do you think it makes sense?

title: Sky DAG optimization algorithm is incorrect for non-chain DAGs
body:
While reading the sky optimizer code, I found that the DP-based optimization algorithm can be incorrect. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

The problem is in determining the optimal cluster for a common predecessor. Consider the following example:

![Screen Shot 2022-03-13 at 1 23 56 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46394894/158077781-9c245bb6-7e06-450e-88a8-44c51addfeec.png)

Let's assume that the computation cost for every task is 0, and the task B and task C must be assigned a cluster at region 1 and region 2 , respectively. Then the optimizer should decide which cluster to assign to task A. Considering the egress cost table, the optimal solution is to run task A at region 1. And the optimal cost is 11.

```python
# Computes dp_best_cost[node][resources]
# = my estimated cost +
#      sum_p min_phw { dp_best_cost(p, phw) +
#                      egress_cost(p, phw, hw) }
# where p in Parents(node).
```
To my understanding, the current optimization algorithm does not always find this solution. The optimizer will calculate the best solution for task B and task C independently; it will assume to run task A at region 1 when computing the best cost for task B, and to run task A at region 2 when computing the best cost for task C. Thus, the optimizer will conclude that the optimal cost is 3, and selects the region for task A depending on how to tie-break the topological order of task B and task C. For some cases, the optimizer will map task A to region 2.

To my knowledge, the common way to solve such an optimization problem is to formulate this as an ILP problem and use an ILP solver. That is, we can formulate the problem as follows:

![Screen Shot 2022-03-13 at 1 40 14 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46394894/158078364-8794ee7a-01a9-47b9-a4c2-004484e57a67.png)

This can be fast solved by any off-the-shelf ILP solver (e.g., Cbc). The problem of minimizing the running time can be solved in a similar manner.

title: Fix the dpkg lock for apt install
body:
Closes #553.

After searching around, it seems that the dpkg lock-frontend is caused by the `unattended-upgrade` service activated in the ubuntu system. This package is enabled by AWS and Azure by default but disabled by GCP (checked by `systemctl status unattended-upgrades`). This PR disables the service to avoid it from holding the dpkg lock.
```
ubuntu@ip-172-31-88-116:~$ sudo lsof /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend
COMMAND    PID USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF  NODE NAME
unattende 4652 root    5uW  REG  202,1        0 60335 /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend
ubuntu@ip-172-31-88-116:~$ ps aux | grep 4652
root      4652 78.9  0.3 370688 107768 ?       Sl   05:24   0:52 /usr/bin/python3 /usr/bin/unattended-upgrade
ubuntu    5262  0.0  0.0  14864  1012 pts/1    S+   05:26   0:00 grep --color=auto 4652
```

Tested:
- [x] `sky cpunode`; the `sudo lsof /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend` has no output; `sudo apt install tree` succeeded.
- [x] `sky launch -c fm-test ./examples/using_file_mounts.yaml`

title: `Sky Down` during Cluster `setup`, `filemounting`, and `run`
body:
Akin to the file locking PR, I propose preventing `sky down` removing the cluster during the `setup`, `filemounting`, and `run` steps. If the cluster is in a running stage/dong stuff, Sky should at least warn the user in the prompt than just `Terminating 2 clusters: hello, test. Proceed?`. Why? Reasons are listed below:

- Deleting is idempotent. If the user has a large cluster, this can be a very costly mistake.

- There are marginally more inconvenient ways to force stop a cluster; the cost of removing the power for the user to down any point of the Cluster status is small. One option is `-f`. Another option is if the user really wanted to tear down the cluster, he/she can ctrl-C out of workdir/setup, filemounting, or run. Then run sky down. This is sufficient power to terminate whenever they want. 

- Other libraries do this too. Kubernetes strongly recommends "draning the node" (depleting resources and then marking node as unschedulable) before tearing it down. (https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/production-environment/tools/kubeadm/create-cluster-kubeadm/#tear-down)

Based on above reasons, as long as the cluster status is Running, `sky down [cluster]` should add to the existing prompt, warning that there are still "jobs" running on the cluster.

title: Add profile message in the execution
body: We may need more profile messages for our execution (`logger.debug()`), so that we can further optimize the time.

title: Upgrading AMI version on AWS
body:
Some reasons we might want to upgrade our AMI:

1) Python3 version is 3.6 (https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/pull/510 requires >=3.7)
2) CUDA version is a bit old (Denial reported that it's too old to compile some stuffs)
3) Many unnecessary conda envs occupying space (50G) and might slow down setup time.

With all that, @Michaelvll and I found the below one might be a better candidate. 
`Deep Learning AMI GPU PyTorch 1.10.0 (Ubuntu 20.04)` that solves above issues.

Before
```
AMI Deep Learning Base AMI (Ubuntu 18.04) Version 50.0 (our default one)

ubuntu@ip-172-31-84-127:~$ python3 --version
Python 3.6.9

ubuntu@ip-172-31-84-127:~$ du --max-depth=1 -h anaconda3/
...
50G     anaconda3/

ubuntu@ip-172-31-84-127:~$ df -h
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/xvda1      249G   97G  152G  39% /

ubuntu@ip-172-31-84-127:~$ nvcc --version
nvcc: NVIDIA (R) Cuda compiler driver
Copyright (c) 2005-2018 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Sat_Aug_25_21:08:01_CDT_2018
Cuda compilation tools, release 10.0, V10.0.130

NVIDIA-SMI 450.142.00   Driver Version: 450.142.00   CUDA Version: 11.0 
```

After
```
Deep Learning AMI GPU PyTorch 1.10.0 (Ubuntu 20.04) 20211023 - ami-0503d0d84bbcbcda5

ubuntu@ip-172-31-6-173:~$ python3 --version
Python 3.9.4
ubuntu@ip-172-31-6-173:~$ conda env list
# conda environments:
#
base                  *  /opt/conda
pytorch                  /opt/conda/envs/pytorch
ubuntu@ip-172-31-6-173:~$ lsb_release -a
Description:    Ubuntu 20.04.3 LTS
Release:        20.04
ubuntu@ip-172-31-6-173:~$ du --max-depth=1 -h /opt/conda
...
8.4G    /opt/conda

ubuntu@ip-172-31-6-173:~$ df -h
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/root        44G   24G   20G  55% /

ubuntu@ip-172-31-6-173:~$ nvcc --version
Copyright (c) 2005-2021 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Mon_May__3_19:15:13_PDT_2021
Cuda compilation tools, release 11.3, V11.3.109
Build cuda_11.3.r11.3/compiler.29920130_0

NVIDIA-SMI 470.57.02    Driver Version: 470.57.02    CUDA Version: 11.4
```

title: [Feature request] Resizing disk size without stopping the instance
body:
Kevin's question: "How to increase VM's disk size when it's out of space?"
AWS/Azure/GCP all support resizing disks. We may want to investigate how to support this on Sky.

title: [Doc] Disk size option should be highlighted in the doc
body:
Kevin's question: "How to adjust disk size?"

We can consider add it to the YAML Configuration section or other tutorials given that adjusting disk size is common.
https://sky-proj-sky.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/reference/yaml-spec.html
